[recto] Good Shepherd. There is a woodcut, XV C. (in Paris) of the Good Shepherd (W.L. Schreiber), N° 839 (mentioned Hind, Woodcut, I, p. 71; It is characteristic of the very late Bruegel that allegorised and symbolical subjects are treated as everyday scenes without obvious symbolical indications, e.g. Peasant's Dance, Wedding Banquet etc.. This appears also to Good & Bad Shepherds. The Good Shepherd treated in 1565 in allegorical fashion. Later Bad & Good Shepherd as just a scene from Peasant Life (the exception: The Misanthrope); [verso] The idea of good and bad shepherd that occupied B's mind, he invented Boston & Princeton composition, but not as Christ pendants. Bad Shepherd see painting attr. to Cornelis Massys, formerly with Harris. See also Stridbeck graphic. Good Shepherd in background of 'Misanthrope'. For subject see 1) Bruegel engraving, John X, 1-16, of Faithful Shepherd (B.122); 2) Holbein: Dance of Death: Bishop: 'Percutiam pastorem, et dispergentur oves' XXXVI Mar.XIIII, Mark XIV, 27; 'Le pasteur aussi frapperay mitres & crosses renversées. Et lors quand ie l' attrapperay, seront ses brebis dispersées.' \* And Jesus saith unto them, All ye shall be offended because of me this night: for it is written (Zechariah XIII, 7), I will smite the shepherd, and the sheep shall be scattered.'; 3) Bol; 4) Engraving van Cleve (Exod.22, 23; 2 Reg 24; Jer 26; John 10; 5) 'Cornelis Massys' Harris.

Pieter Bruegel the Younger, 423. Christ and the Woman Taken in Adultery. After the composition of P.B.I. dated 1575 preserved in P. Perret's engraving of 1579. Christ is robed in pale blue, the adulteress in dark blue. Red Yellow and blue predominate in the costumes of the remaining figures. Signed on left: P. BREVGHEL. Panel, 10 1/2 x 15 5/8 in.

Murder of Innocents: Alba. The commander of the soldiers with his long white beard nearest to Alba portrait as it appears in the anonymous engraving of Jacques Jonghelincks' statue erected in the Antwerp citadel 1568, destroyed by Requesens 1574. Repr. e.g. in [Henri] PIRENNE, Hist. de Belgique [= Histoire de Belgique des origines à nos jours, Bruxelles: Renaissance du Livre, 1948-1952] illustr[ated] quarto ed. 194..[sic], II, p. 273 (B[ritish] M[useum] 9414.m.4). This is certainly the prototype of the painting; cf. also (though here he looks different) the anonymous satyrical print showing Alba seated above the corpses of Egmont & Hoorn, at his side a centaure with 3 heads (Cardinals Guise, Lorraine, Granvelle). Alba devours a child. The inscription; [verso] in Flemish & French says: [... ] reprod. p. 274: A portrait of Alba (repr. p. 289) by an unknown painter (Coll. of Duke of Berwick & Alba, Madrid) said to represent him of the age of 74, shows him with long white beard.

BRUEGEL: Dulle Griet (1562) The head of Hell comparable to the head of Monster, one of, the garden sculptures in the garden of Bomarzo (nr. Viterbo) which is discussed and well reproduced in Franzsepp Würtenberger, Mannerism, London [New York: Holt, Rinehart & Winston], 1963 (original German edition, Schroll, Vienna 1962), p. 151f, colour pl. p. 153. According to Würtenberger commissioned by Vicino Orsini, c. 1560, the park within sight of Orsini castle; André CHASTEL, The Crisis of the Renaissance, [1520-1600, Geneva] (Skira), English language edition 1968, p. 140 has reproduction of Dragon fighting a lion and a lioness 1552, sculpture in Tufa rock. Castle Park Bomarzo near Viterbo; [verso][toegevoegde vermeldling]: 'F.G. neither Würtenberger nor Chastel give the designer's or sculptor's name.

Death of the Virgin. The Louvre drawing (Lugt, Inventaire ...Maîtres des Anciens Pays-Bas nés avant 1550, [Paris: Éditions des musées nationaux], 1968, N° 274) is a copy after the Upton House picture, not after the print (see especially the back of the chair in the foreground). Lugt puts forward other arguments for copy after painting and reject the theory of M. Jaffé (who reproduces the Louvre drawing in his article in Master Drawings 'Rubens as a collector of Drawings') that the drawing was retouched by Rubens.

BRVEGEL: Suicide of Saul. Why did Bruegel paint this rare subject? What is its deeper meaning? The motif also appears in Holbein's Old Testament woodcuts - but treated. Old Test. Samuel I, 31 (also Samuel II, I) Mount Gilboa -  a mountain also with Holbein II Samuel, who is more [onleesbaar] to text.

Bruegel & Tapestries. The early Adoration of the Magi (Brussels) in its main lines of composition based on the tapestry of the same subject in the series/scenes from the Cult of Christ in the Vatican (Eugène Müntz, Les tapisseries de Raphael au Vatican, Paris 1897, p. 37) woven in the workshop of Pieter van Aelst, Brussels, 1520-1531. The design is not by Raphael himself but school. (There is a large elephant in the tapestry, as well as camels). The Resurrection of this series is the direct model for P. Coecke's Resurrection (also noticed by Kronig). Motifs from the Massacre of the Innocents survives in Vermeyen's Turcs picture and in Bruegel's Massacre. The Christ of the Ascension echoed in the Christ of Bruegel's Resurrection. If the composition of the Adoration is reversed as it appeared in the cartoon the relation to Bruegel is even closer.

The attribution of the Deluge in Peter [sic] Bruegel the Elder is in my view not convincing. The picture does not fit into any period of his career. A certain relation to the engraved so-called Small Landscape series is no support for an attribution to P. Bruegel, as this series is certainly not by Bruegel. [...][scan]

Bay of Naples, Nos. 7: From the North; 8: From the South (lent by Duke of Northumberland; N° 15 From the South (Lent by the Louvre). The shape of the jetty not recognisable in the too distant and circle view of the bay; but something of the roundness of the bay seen from teh land side is suggested and this is what Bruegel tried to give in his closer view.

[recto] Ad [Addendum] View of Naples. A typical bird's eye view of the sea with ships, and with the shore in the background decoration like in Huys cf. Print of John Pine (1739) after tapestries by the painter Hendrik Cornelisz. Vroom of Haarlem ordered by Charles Lord Howard, and woven by Francis Spiering London (1739). Attack on the Spanish Armada by the English Fleet, July 1588 repr. in (R. [Roland] Mousnier, Les XVIe et XVIIe siècles, [les progrès de la civilisation européenne et le déclin de l'Orient (1492-1715)], (Histoire générale des civilisations IV), Paris [Presses universitaires de France], 1954, pl. 18, whence these incorrect information; [verso] see [Horace] Walpole, [Anecdotes of Painting in England: with some Account of the Principal Artists, London: Chatto and Windus, 1876], I, 168 & 169 + notes & Sandrart, p. 147. The Tapestries burnt in the Commons 1834. Commissioned rather by Earl of Nottingham, Lord High Admiral of England (according to Walpole) Sandrart speaks of Howard [sic].

[recto] Conversion of Paul. In L. van Leyden's print the conversion (Paulus blinded by divine ray) in background; in foreground the soldiers (with the blind Paul); B. [Berthold] Riehl, Geschichte des Sittenbildes in der deutschen Kunst bis zum Tode Pieter Breughel des Älteren, Berlin & Stuttgart [Spemann], 1884, citaat p. 89; [verso] [toegevoegde vermelding]: F.G. The composition of Bruegel's picture in fact developed from Lucas: The event placed in mountainous country; the rock rising steeply and at the [onleesbaar] a hidden view in the distant land below; also the procession as such, though this treated relief-like [onleesbaar] leading into depth, but some of the figures half hidden by & emerging from the rocks. A painting of the subject by P.B.II strongly influenced by L's print (see Lucas exh. [= B.L.D. (ed.),  Lucas van Leyden en tijdgenoten], Rotterdam 1952, N° 20).

[Briefhoofd: University of Washington, Seattle] Bruegel: Sermon of St. John. Meaning. The Sermon (the true message of Christ) is meant for the whole world. The orientals (man with turban near left border), Jews (Rabbi to the right of the tree in yellow dress), pilgrims (in front), gipsies, soldiers, and later on monastics orders are founded). Bottom right with monk of Antonite order (with T on his dress), Virgin Mary (just below epileptic boy (= enthusiam: message also for sick people?[sic])) also present. Message to mankind. In most copies the proportions are different from the Budapest original (unless the latter has cut down at the top) and the trees continue at the top a great deal beyond the two boys who have climbed up the trees.[scan]

[recto] Ad [Addendum] 42. WASHINGTON, Nat. Gallery of Art. Paintings and sculpture from the Kress Collection. Acquired by the Samuel H. Kress Foundation 1945-1951, Washington 1951 (Catalogue by W. Suida), p. 204. [nr.] 90 Pieter Bruegel the Elder, Landscape with the Temptation of St. Anthony (repr. p. 205) Since its rediscovery this painting has been recognized as a work by P. Bruegel and published by L. van Puyvelde (Pantheon XV, 1935), M.J. Friedländer (N.Mal. XIV, 1937), G. Glück (1936 &Jb. 1935). These critics agree that it is one of the earlier paintings by P.B. of about 1557-1558, and that it shows close connection with the landscape in the coll. Stuyck del Bruyère dated 1557 (now on exhibition as a loan in the N.G. of Art Washington; [verso] Charles de Tolnay (1935), on the other hand, considers it an early work by Jan Bruegel. Wood, Oak: 2211/15 x 33 9/16in. (57,8 x 85,3 cm). Formerly in the coll. of the Countess Montblanc, Belgium. L. van Puyvelde (Pantheon XV, 1935) says the painting was overpainted and neglected until one day et fell down from the wall, so that repairs became inevitable. When cleaned it was recognized as a P.B. S.H. Kress Coll. New York 1950. Exh. Brussels 1935, Paris Orangerie 1936(7) Baltimore Mus. of Art 1943 & 1948; Raleigh, the Carolina State Society Art Gallery, 1943.

Bruegel sein, kommt also hier nicht in Betrachtung.

Bruegel & Massys Followers. An early attempt at large figure composition influenced by Massys and followers as e.g. Jan Massys & Hemessen, partly parallel with Bosch influneces 'Cutting the Stone', Doyen de Renaix (Bast. 1921) 1556 or 1557, Witch of Malleghem 1559., 1558 Alchemist, 1559 Elck; Late reminiscence in [onleesbaar] 1565; This 1556-58/9 group stylistically rather isolated in B's work. What about Cornelis Massys?; Marlier, p. 198 Only few paintings by Jan Massys of 1st period (-1544) known, second period 1558ff.

Babel Vienna. The two large ships in the foreground on the right. Bruegel used them for drawings which were also used for the ship series, but the sails are rolled up - the boats are in harbour: 1) the boat on the right, cf. Nef de Bande, Bast.100 with one man climbing up the "Takelage" and another  on a pole at the end of the ship - identical the same ship again in Icarus and reversed in the left foreground of Naples; 2) the other boat strongly foreshortened central of three ships in Bast.104, also Bast. 106.
The Listener, April 2, 1953, vol. XIX, N° 1257: The Resurrection, a carved panel of Flemish origin in the church of St. Mary the Virgin, Knowsley, Lancashire [ill.]

[verso] Bruegel in Spain: 1) Bosch motifs taken from Spanish Boschs-show detailed study of certain Bosch's particularly 'Hay Cart'; 2) Years until Large Landscape Series (1555) not accounted for. Th eseries not dated, but the preliminary drawing in the Louvre (T. 23) for Bosch N° 9 i sdated 1555. He may have been away all that time. (The earliest figure drawings (Fish, T. 44, & Ass in School, T. 45, dated 1556). This would explain why no earlier painting; [verso] Against Spain: 1) Th elong absence may be due to stay in Italy; 2) The Return journey led through Austria & Germany; 3) Van Mander does not mention stay in Spain; 4) No Spanish landscapes by Bruegel? [doorstreept]; 5) The main pictures of importance  for Bruegel were 1) Last Judgment [onleesbaar], lost); 2) Epiphany, Prado; 3) Vienna Last Judgment (4) Hay Cart. Of these Prado Epiphany was confiscated by Philip II from Jean de Casembrot (when & where?) and there exist many copies and Hay Cart there was a version in Arundel Coll. [onleesbaar] Jeronimo Bos (p. 285)

[recto] Details. Many details but never overemphasized subordened to composition and to meaning (Inhalt) Suggestion of motion [onleesbaar] background figures and landscape. Full plastic main figures. Die Bewegung in den Raum - dynamischen Raumerlebnis (gibt es das in den Kalender Miniaturen von 1500? Die Dynamik: Bewegung in und aus dem Raum auch in der Jänner Limburg bei den M. de Vos die Figuren auch die Herde mit den anderen Reiter Figuren vereinigen konnte.'

Ad [Addendum] 76. For catalogue of lost pictures by Bruegel: The Temptation of Christ. Van Mander mentions a Temptation of Christ waer [=daer] men van boven...[sic] The conception of a mountainous landscape with a view down from the mountains which are so high that clouds in [onleesbaar] then in Paulus... Drawing in Louvre. T. [= Tolnay] has drawn attention a painting (fig. 152) in; [verso] an Amsterdam private collection of a Temptation of Christ with a vast mountainous landscape and Christ quite [onleesbaar] by Lucas van Valckenborch. The height with the clouds and the [onleesbaar] trees almost literally reproduced from the Paulus seem suggest fact that a Moses on Mount Sinai by T. Verhaecht in the coll. of F. Lugt, the Hague, may be closer to the lost Temptation. Das Bild schon bei Glück, N° 49 herausgegeben.

[vouwblad] General Introduction. Bruegel & Van der Goes. Vanbeselaere sees connection between Monforte Altar & Bruegel's N.G. Adoration - not convincing. More correct Fierens-Gevaert. Fierens contention that Patinir Shepherds precursor of Bruegel's peasants. I think the bare December trees with leading into depth and forming a pattern impressed Bruegel in: Return of Herd, Hunters, Gloomy Day, Bird Trap, Census at Bethlehem, Murder of Innocents, Reinhart Adoration, Carneval. [recto] Claudine Majzels, (Penn University) but Canadian (\*)(\*) later married in Scotland (Webster or Fletcher?), lecture on Dance and Movement in Bruegel, in Gombrich Seminar, 26-2-75. Showed dance as negative (sinful) in Brant, Narrenschiff illustration Dance around Golden Calf. Bosch, Haywain (outside in background). Proved that in Vienna 'Peasant Meal'  the 'third foot' belonges to the seated man who hands on the 'porridge' to the bride. The child in the foreground may be wearing the bridegroom's 
head[gear] Gombrich: Bruegel's Joke that the bridegroom is not represented at all and one has to look for him. Majzels has discovered couple of lovers in above the straw in the barn and suggests that the Vienna Peasant Dance is a continuation to the right of the Peasant Meal with common perspective; [verso] Majzels points to the spoon (lepel) in the hats of the men carrying the door and of the old dancer in the Peasant Dance.

Bruegel: Storm at Sea. For late Bruegel speaks that it is a composition like the late lost ones: Shepherd, Peasant Pair attacked etc. with a vast plain which seems to be in movement: the sea is a plain in movement- with much sky above it-all earlier marine pictures (also Bruegel's own) give much more prominence to the ships which are always much larger. (The Polnitz picture is not a marine picture - but an estuary with rocks) and this is also clear when compared with Palma Vecchio's S.Marco saves Venice (Giorgione Exh. 1955, N° 89) [Pietro Zampetti (ed.], Giorgione e il giorioneschi, Venezia , Palazzo Ducale, 1955] with which there is some contact.

Ad [Addendum] Bruegel. British Museum. exhibition of Sung & Yuan painting from Metropolitan Museum of Art, New York, 22 Cloudy Mountains by Fang Tsung-I (c. 1300-1378) Shows winding river with aerial perspective of mountains in right foreground with strong dark brushstrokes - like Bruegel. Generally the winding river (Bosch, Patinr, etc.) in Chinese painting much earlier than in Europe (perhaps maybe coming from China to Europe) also the stress on rocks (Bruegel, Valckenborch) and plant in foreground (Vienna Way to calvary) probably derived from East.

Naer het Leven. Meaning of the words: Costumes were copied from costume books-This was the usual practice.  The words indicate in this case that the drawings were done from life, from actual observation of the peasants, as van Mander said of Bruegel [...]

March 1962. Crucifixion Spink. Certain features derived from Bruegel's Way to Calvary of 1564. In Mary's group on left the woman in despair is wether 'Mary Magdalen' from the Bruegel of 1564 also the peddlar with the basket. The ground [onleesbaar] quite different from B. Outlined in brown lines: architecture and figures on right. Man under cross in green - white stupid Lovers seen from back. Red staffage in centre. Distribution of red spots similar to Vienna Calvary. Line pale green with hightened with lighter green in bushes on right. Horsemen under cross seen from back cf. Conversion of St. Paul. Figures seen from back in background painted broadly and almost monochrome like Dutch XVII. P. Baltens or M. van Cleve? [...][scan]

Tower of Babel. Der Bruegel's Turm von Babel hat van Mander seine besonderheit richtig erkannt: "Man kann auch von oben in den Turm hineinsehen" sagt er. Ahnlich stellt ihm auf bei der Versuchung Christi,  "dass man von oben, wie in der Alpen, niederblickt auf der Städte u. Länder..." [= Er hat ferner eine Versuchung Christi gemalt. Der Vorgang spielt sich hier in einer Alpenlandschaft ab, und man sieht von oben an manchen Stellen durch Wolkenspalten auf Städte und Gefilde hinab], was auch Tatsache des Neue von Bruegel's Landschaft ist.

Das Kind hat den Lasterhut eines Grosser - es ist selbst noch zu klein für andere Laster ausser Gula - aber es wird später auch solche haben- oder ist 'Pride' eines der Laster das man schon bei Kinder findet? And who is completely absorbed in licking the delicious food in a picture of innocent greed. Neu Kinder vertreten das schlechte Prinzip ganz allgemeins.'

Man on left in white violet short jacket over white shirt, trousers reddish grey brown not in good condition (stippled by restorer). Man on right greenish grey, over white shirt. In the fleshparts of both some red with white highlights. Brown eyes. The man on the ladder: black grey, trousers, greenish blue jacket, grey & hair cap; [blad 1, verso] The tool greenish blue like the dress - very heavy no detail. Trunk of the tree on which this man is working simply grey-very little differentiated. The brandles of faggots grey with white highlights. Some parallel strokes of underdrawing in white shirt of man on right. Soil, brown, and behind this green (meadow) very summary. Left leg of man with a kind of pentimenti; [blad 2, recto] The forest- green shrubs on left and centre; the tree trunks and branches dark brown grey with reddish and white highlights. Black cap on the ground bottom left (next to purse) black with grey spots, but without the 'pointllist' quality of P.B.I-too coarse. The whistle on the right does not appear in teh X-ray photograph. Grey trousers of right man painted broadly in P.B.I manner; [blad 2, verso] On back old number in [schema]. Provenance: Prince Wallenstein? in Germany or rather Oethinger-Wallenstein? There is a lithographed (1826?) and MS Catal. (1827) in Munich, Photostats in Nat. Gall. Better than Barber Institute. Oethinger-Wallenstein Coll. see also G. Grupp, in Jahrbuch des histor. Vereins für Nordlingen & Umgebung, VI, 1907, pp. 73ff. (All this about Oethinger-Wallenstein Coll. according to N.G. Catal. German School. Sale of Oethinger-Wallenstein Coll. at Kensington Pal. 1848, bt by Prince Consort.

Shortly before midday a Hr. Knecht, collector in Zürich, Seebacher Strasse 171, telephoned from Zürich to inquire about the picture N°1 (Sailing Ships & Burning Town) in the earlier editions of my Bruegel paintings, which I have withdrawn from the 3rd edition. It was offered to him by a German dealer whose name he was not permitted to disclose. I told him that I have withdrawn the picture from the 3rd edition because after recent study of the original in London, I no longer believed in Bruegel's authorship. I asked him not to tell the dealer that he had spoken to me which he promised (as this was also in his interest). He did not give me the price asked, saying that this was being negotiated.

Bruegel: Sermon of St. John. Christ present-separated on the right. In the crowd orientals (gipsy woman with child), soldiers (Landsknechte) all this in Patinir's Baptism of Christ, Vienna (detail, Koch, Patinir, Fig. 9) and less clearly in Patinir's Preaching of St. John in Brussels (Koch, Fig. 10) & workshop replica in Philadelphia (Koch, Fig. 11). Considering the connection with the clouds in Vienna Tower of Babel and the fact that the Baptism was with Leop. Wilh., i.e. in the Netherlands until mid 17th. C., it is very likely that Bruegel knew Patinir's Baptism.

[Tekening FG in potlood].[recto] 'The Deluge', Panel, 9 3/4 x 17 3/4 inches, ex. Masing Coll. Vienna. Certificates by Friedländer (A'dam 15-2-54) & Valentiner (Los Angeles Jan. 16, 55): Pieter Bruegel the Elder; [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. Not P.B.I, does not fit, into any of his periods. A certain relation to the engraved small landscapes series does not prove Bruegel's authorship; [verso] as these are not by Bruegel. Above all the vedute character speaks against P.B. It is a work derived from him, the landscape silhouette or the horizon to be compared with Winterlandscape with Bird Trap. The stressing of the white speak against P. Bruegel. The trees are coarse when in my view correspond with his. It is the work of a close follower of Bruegel. The fine painting of the ducks so different from P.B. birds, might possibly indicate Jan Brueghel the Younger, but cf. also Jacob Grimmer, Village Street, fully signed and dated 1583 (or 1589) De Boer Exh. 1934, N° 128 (pl. 18). Photograph shown by Hallsborough 17-7-57.[scan]

Stay in Italy. For longer stay in Italy speeks the fact that Clovio was in Rome only 1553-1556 so Bruegel workinbg with him may well have stayed in Rome into 1554. Dr. Feste was here with the picture on Oct. 16, 1978 and left the enclosed material. I suggested he should go to the Rijksbureau and told him that the picture was certainly from the circle of P. Brueghel the Younger. He promised to send one colour reproduction and get me Horst Vey, Anton van Dyck. He gave me as a present a belt buckle of the State of Texas.

Looks better than Johnson, [onleesbaar]  that like in Bruggmann & Hay versions, sleeve like Johnson. More complete than Johnson: Landscape extending on left & better beyond bare tree; on the right beyond the baretree (which is richer in detail) the 2 standing sheep [onleesbaar] in pure profile, head not turned; above this sheep two lambs or sheep shy above (although lower than Johnson). In both pictures the jerkin tied with dark laces, in Hay version with light one; 2) [sic] Dagger nearer to [onleesbaar], head more; [blad 1, verso]turned, more running than in Johnson; 3) Advertisement in Connoisseur (Date?), signed, 52 x 35 inches, including frame, for sale; [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. based on Beague version, but trees altered; some leaves added to tree on right, tree with dense dense foliage on left: Here it is not just the hair which is in disorder, but a cap falling from his head. Clear shadow of dagger; 4) Hay version. Clearly based on Beague, but shadow of dagger added and lack of understanding of bare trees; 5) not in Witt. Bruggmann: J. Brueghel.

[vouwblad] [recto] Christ & the Woman taken in Adultery. The man on the right to be compared with Man on the right in Andrea del Sarto's Sermon of St. John (Scalzi, c. 1515) (repr. Wölfflin, Classic Art, p. 162)[= Heinrich Wölfflin, Classic Art : An Introduction to the Italian Renaissance, London: Phaidon, 1953] which according to Wölfflin is derived from Dürer, i.e. from 'Christ shown to the People' - Small Engraved Passion, B. 10). Bruegel seems nearer to Sarto than to Dürer and there are other features in Sarto (Christ present; [verso] at Sermon) which makes it appear likely that Bruegel knew the Sarto's picture. Sarto to be studied in this connection: 1) Are there any other traces of Sarto frescoes in B's work?; 2) Were there engravings of this work in Bruegel's scène?; For composition of Adulteress cf. also Sarto's Scene from Life of Filippo Benizzi, Annunziata (Wölfflin, p. 159). The monumental figures of the Apostles perhaps nearer to Sarto than Raphael, e.g. cf. Arrest of St. John, Wölfflin, p. 165 and in particular Annunciation to Zacharias figure on left cf. with left Apostle in Bruegel's composition of Adulteress cf. with Woman centre of Sarto's Birth of the Virgin in Annunziata (Wölfflin, pl. XII).

The Procession to Calvary. A condemnation of the people's attitude. The soldiers rough, for the [onleesbaar] it is a curious spectacle, same for the left, are completely unconcerned. The wife of Simon of Cyrene who is himself reluctant to help Christ, resists although she has a rosary. 'Unfaithful shepherd abondons his lamb' (though it belongs to Simon of Cyrene). Some want to make business: peddlar a most conspicious figure in front. Only few readly mourn: the right bottom corner and 2 women the men standing near Christ. What is the meaning of the wind mill?

[recto] Jan Brueghel-Chronology difficult influence of Coninxloo (foliage) already e.g. visible in pictures painted in Italy, as e.g. Sermon on the Mount dated 1594 on copper (Vienna)(private coll. St. Lucas[onleesbaar] (PBI, N°25, Pl. VI). He must have see pictures by Coninxloo (have worked with him on his way to Italy for in 1596 Coninxloo settled for good in Amsterdam. In 1585 Coninxloo was at Frankfurt and here Brueghel may have met him on his way from Cologne to Italy. The foliage itself whether in the manner of Coninxloo or not voluminous but in little strokes, does not help for dating: because the 2 manners seem to be used contemporaneously, e.g. the little strokes appear in Hannover supposedly 1591 (in Italy) in version dated 1601 and something derived from Coninxloo but open [onleesbaar] not with voluminous hardway with horse skeleton 1608 (Dresden). Hard to say when he began to work after paintings by his father. The Graz Triumph of Death is dated 1597 (Perhaps the Valckenisse Triumph; Childrens Games Valckenisse 1676 Helsche B.[verso] other pictures listed as Helsche Bruegel may refer to J.B. See also Hairs about Forchoudt's remark. Copies by J.B. after P.B. Documented old Inventories: Triumph of Death; Sermon of St. John; Quarrel at Cards. Wann kommt Name Fluweelen Bruegel auf? Look up Denucé. Importance of Muziano for J.B. (S. Klauner & Oldenbourg, p. 21).

A further argument in favour of 12 months: The paintings done for Jonghelinck executed with meticulous care & finish. Tower of Babel, Procession. In the Months Bruegel did not have enough time. The 2nd picture: Hunters in the snow, Dark Day, Hay Making done with great care - Corn Harvest, Return of the Herd in parts only laid on, without complete finish - this would indicated that Jonghelinck wanted them at a certain date, but the great number of paintings to be executed forced this manner of working by Bruegel.

W.] Turner, Oxford [Clarendon Press], 1939 (already) oval water colour (by Turner c. 1788) of 'St. Vincent's Tower, Napels'. This was adopted from the central portion of Paul Sandby's, aquatint after [Pietro] FABRIS entitled 'Port of Naples, with the Ruined of Tower of St. Vincent', published in 1778... As so many liberties have been taken (by Turner) with the original it seems probable that it was not worked direct from the engraving, but from a hasty sketch made perhaps from a printseller's window; [verso] The drawing has been reproduced together withe the relevant portion of Sandby's engraving in my study [= Finberg] of [onderstreept] Turner's Sketches and Drawings (1910).

[recto] Peasants Wedding.  B.M.[British Museum] Printroom (after Detroit composition but extented). J. [Jan] Bisschop after Bruegel (from Fenwick coll.). Agrees perfectly with Detroit, only the trees of which only the trunks appear in Detroit continued to foliage and therefore not so high horizon, in this zone (above Bruegel's original horizon landscape looks like added by Bisschop. Bisschop's framing tree trunk on the left, missing in Detroit, was certainly in the original (perhaps Detroit cut down) -  [kantlijn] Query: can the cutting down be checked or the original?-  here and on the right, where a figure cut in half by the picture's edge is almost complete in Bisschop. On the other hand in Bisschop's version the figures are nearer, there is more ground at the bottom in Detroit. The main difference however is the bride's tapestry hanging down in a curve [schema] (hung on a rope probably) in Detroit, but straight [schema] hung over a stick the ends of which are fixed in two trees, in Bisschop's version. In Spiridon the Bride's table & tapestery missing. Van der Heyden the tapestery like at Detroit [sic]; [verso] Print by [Guillaume Henri] Franquinet from Denon's picture is the other composition with the bagpipers on the left - this composition seems to be based on the Van der Heyden composition, the main differences being that the bagpiper's face in [Vivant] Denon & later is seen en face, in Van der Heyden in profile and a tree introduced on the right. Provisional conclusion: Apart from Vienna there seems to have been two compositions by Bruegel: 1) Van der Heyden; 2) Detroittype - with bagpipers transferred to right and altitude of dancer on right border turned into the Valkenburg altitude. Query: Is it possible that Van der Heyden gives the composition in reverse?

[recto] BRVEGEL-RUBENS: A general rule: new features appear first as small scale subordinated parts of a picture. Still life, landscape added in window or background in XV becomes dominant in XVI. Painterly Bruegel's treatment of background landscape e.g. the plain in background in the right of the Babel Tower of Vienna with the trees brushed in irregular becomes a general characteristic of late Rubens landscape and an independent picture; [verso] Boston, Fine arts Museum (Glück 23) as e.g. in Birmingham, Barber Inst. Landscape (Glück, 23A) or much more decisive background ? as in N. Gall. Steen (Glück 30). Of course Rubens general also took over arrangement of landscape - as Glück has noticed.

L. van Valckenborch. 7 Towers of Babel as Valckenborch, among these one in Munich, Pinakothek nearest to Bruegel clearly based on Bruegel's Van Beuningen version; Ad Tower of Babel generally: 1) The Vienna picture is Nimrod's visit to the town; 2) The Van Beuningen picture is the building of the tower; [verso] more Towers of Babel under Maerten van Valckenborch.

[recto] Death of Virgin.The chiaroscuro effect, unsual for Bruegel and only partly to be found in his grisailles (Resurrection, Adulteress and partly in Wise & Foolish Virgins) comes from the graphic arts. N. Hogenberg, Death of Margaret, the direct prototype for, is only one of the examples typical of this artist, there are e.g. other 4 Evangelists etchings after Frans Crabbe (Hollstein, V, Crabbe, Nos. 38-41 (p. 86, see also [Arthur E.] Popham, [= Engravings and Etchings of Frans Crabbe van Espleghem”], The Print Collector's Quarterly, 22, 3, [1935], pp. 202 & 203) of which the Evangelist St. Mark is signed NH and only this one of the whole set is listed by Hollstein (IX, p. 60) under N. Hogenberg, N°19. Cf. also the engraving by Crabbe (signed with cray-fish) of Christ on Mount of Olives (Hollstein, V, Crabbe, N° 11). Both Crabbe and N. Hogenberg were Malines artists as well as Frans Verbeeck (Schüler Crabbes?) and Bruegel's mother -in- law who was born at Malines; [verso] Death of Virgin. [Heinrich] Th. Musper, Die Holzschnitte des Nicolas Hogenberg aus München, Jb.pr. Ksl. [= Jahrbuch der Preußischen Kunstsammlungen], LXIII, 1942, pp. 171-179, citaten pp. 178-179.

[vouwblad] Sermon of St. John the Baptist. The figure placed obliquely by and leaning on a tree trunk (on the right) appears as woman and seen from the front- in Paolo Veronese's Sermon of St. John in the Borghese, see Mostra di [Paolo] Veronese, Venice 1939, N° 45 (the detail is reproduced on p. 47 [sic= p. 113]). Here also St. John points at Christ and there are oriental -turbaned- listeners: the turbaned figure on the left in Bruegel's painting reminiscent of [Gentile] Bellini - [Vittorio] Carpaccio. Could there not be a common prototype for Bruegel & Veronese? Bruegel's crowd might have a predecessor in the Bellini-Carpaccio circle. [Rodolfo] Palluchini in the catal[ogue] of the Mostra di Veronese gives detailed biography for the picture and dates it 'forse di poco antecente al ciclo d'affreschi di Maser' (which he dates in first half seventh decennium of XVI century). Shape of turban in Bruegel's picture on [onleesbaar] with thin point in centre cf. with turban of Negro King in Veronese's Adoration in Vienna ([onleesbaar], Veronese, Abb. 69, adest). Has the turkish turban been transmitted to Bruegel via Venice or was this turban general?

[recto] Catal.N°2: Landscape with Christ Calling Peter; [kantlijn links] The smaller rock in the water in Christ Landscape very similar to Rocks in de Boer; Very near to De Boer Landscape: Trees at edges of rocks silhouetted in the same way. The composition: river leading straight into depth (not diagonal) the same, with flanking rocks in foreground, higher as left, lower on right. The structure (and texture) of the rocks different. Sharp brittle in Christ Landscape softer in de Boer picture. Lighting the rains: dark foreground light in background. Rocks seen silhouetted against the light. Boats with figures in water in both;The Figures in Christ calling Peter. The 2 men at the shore, cf. men in Insidiosus Auceps (B. 10). Sheep cf. Plaustrum Belgicum (B. II) Christ cf. Joseph & Virgin in Fuga Deiparae Aegyptum (B.15); for drapery of Christ also Magdalene Poenitens (B.8). The straight orthogonal foreshortening – instead of the later diagonal - of the river also in Prospectus Tyburtinus (B.3); [verso] The birch tree trunk lying on the road precursor of tree trunk in Children’s Games and the trunk on right in ‘February’. Waves not quite to wild, but related in character to waves in ‘Shipwreck’ by Bles in Napels (Baldass Jb.34, 1918, Fig.26) [= Ludwig Baldass, Die niederländische Landschaftsmalerei von Patinir bis Bruegel, in: Jahrbuch der kunsthistorischen Sammlungen in Wien, 34 (1918), Heft 4, pp. 112-157]; The tiny figures in the field – very fine like in de Boer & in later pictures e.g. Stuyck Landscape.[scan]

[recto] Flußlandschaft, Nat. Gallery von Glück Bruegel zugeschrieben. Die Situation ist wohl so: das Bild ist stilistischer alter als Bruegel, nähe zu Patinier. Die übereinstimmung mit (Rückenfigur, des zeichnendes Malers, Floß) dem Bild und der Radierung Bastelaer N° 1 wohl zu erklären entweder aus gemeinsamen Vorbild oder Bruegel direkt von diesen Bild. Der zeichnende Künstler bei Vermeyen in den Tunis Serie (Bild...) [?] hier zwar als Bericht erstatten; s. neuere Notizen in Glück, Bruegel & Antiquity; [verso] den einen Prinzip doch schon der ersten Hälfte XVI. [?] Glück erwähnt außerdem eines Florentiner Kupferstich mit dem Motiv, Ende, XV). Glück betont die reine Landschaft (ohne gegenstande [?]) hier ganz früh, abert früher schon Altdorfer [?] ohne [?] Figuren.

'Der Kindermord zu Bethlehem' von Pieter Brueghel dem Jüngeren. Im Besitz von Prof. Dr.med. Fritz Ludwig, [adres] Bern [...]. Erworben ca. 1935 aus dem Nachlass von Konsul Schauwecker in Bern. Oel auf Holz, parkettiert. Masse: 104 cm breit, 72 cm hoch. Rechts unten signiert P.BREVGHEL. Vergl. dasselbe Motiv 'The Massacre of the Innocents', by Pieter Brueghel the Younger, Oil on panel, 281/2 x 411/2 inches, im Besitz von Major George Howard, Castle Howard, Yorkshire. Das Bild gelangte im späten 190 Jahrhundert in die Sammlung im Castle Howard. Reproduziert in 'The Connoisseur', London, August 1958, Seite 26.

T (richtig) [onleesbaar]. Wir wissen nicht, wie lange er in Italien war. Eine Zeichnung 1552 datiert (T. 2) zeigt ital. Architektur die späteren Birglandschaften datiert T. um 1554, scheint also diese Zeit noch Abwesenheit von Antw. anzunehmen. Der Stich von Georgs Tor Eislauf wae für Friedländer Anhaltspunkt für Anwesenheit in Antw. 1553 aber Friedländer selbst sagt, der Stich nicht  [onleesbaar] zuverlässig sein muß; [verso] [...][scan]

Saul's Suicide. [Johann] Fischart Text zu Stimmer-Bibel 1576, 80, I.Reg.XXXI, I. Paralip. XL. Der Verfolger Davids verfolgt sich selbs. Saul sah sein Volk und Sön erschlagen/ und that am Herzen gar verzagen/ Fül im sein schwerd/ sich selbs erstach/ Solchs that auch sein Schilttrager nach: Im selbs thun rach/ ists Gots gröst schmach. The composition shows a certain similarity to Bruegel's, Holbein's (Hind 37)[= Arthur M. Hind, An Introduction to a History of Woodcut. [With a Detailed Survey of the Work Done in the Fifteenth Century, London: Constable], 1935] is quite different.

[1 blad] Temptation of St. Anthony, Washington. The J. W. de COCK woodcut with Temptation of St. Anthony (Friedländer, XI, pl. XLVI; Hollstein, IV, p. 192; Franz, pl.[sic] contains in the Temptation scene in the air several similar motifs: the demon riding on a fish, with a knife in the print, a spear in the painting, below this to the right of the main group a serpent with wings; the general outlaws of this group with monsters raising their arms with weapons. This woodcut with the animal covered by a brailing cloak on the right & a figure riding on its back provided the model for the corresponding group in Bruegel's Luxuria drawing.

[recto] Ad [Addendum] Sermon of St. John 23. [David Adrian] Freedberg, [Iconoclasm and Painting in the Netherlands: 1566-1609, s.l.: s.n., 1972], p. 20 Hedge-services in openair, field preaching 1566 (Flemish Hagepreek- for meaning & etymology see R. FRUIN, 'Haagpreek', in Verspreide Geschriften VIII (The Hague 1903), p. 307-313; [...] Freedberg, p. 21: Services held under armed guards, after Margaret edicts at the beginning of July 1566. Everywhere great; [verso] crowds of men, women & children gathered on the outskirts of the towns to listen to the preachers, who often arrived with an additional guard for themselves [...]. There are many descriptions of these (hedge) services in the early chronicles, e.g. F. STRADA, De Bello Gallico. Decas prima (1555-1579), Rome, 1632, p. 117, F. HARAEUS, De Initiis Tumultum Belgicorum, Douai 1587, pp. 221-222.

Cornelisz Engelbrechtsz or Jan de Cock. The Procession to Calvary, Panel 12 1/8 x 16 7/8 inches, Yale University Art Gallery New Haven, Connecticut. Cornelis Engelbrechtsz. (Leyden) trained 3 sons as well as Aertgen & Lucas van Leyden. Jan de Cock (Jan van Leyden) must sometime have been associated with Cornelis'circle; De Cock is known to have worked in Antwerp...[sic] Sirén attributed this picture to Engelbrechtsz., Friedländer (tentatively) Winkler & Held to Jan de Cock. Hoogewerff ascribed it to a son of Engelbrechtsz., Lucas Cornelisz., while Valentiner has suggested the name of another of the painter's sons, Cornelis Cornelisz.Kunst by whom van Mander knew a Christ Carrying the Cross. Held has shown that a larger version of the present painting once existed and was apparently very famous as it is pursued in several early copies and variants. 
[Osvald] SIRÉN, A Descriptive Catalogue of the Pictures in the Jarves Collection belonging to Yale University, New Haven [Yale University Press] 1916, pp. 271-272, ill.; FRIEDLÄNDER, XI, 1934, pp. 65, 126, N°13; [Friedrich] WINKLER, Die altniederländische Malerei, [Berlin: Propylaën-Verlag](1924), p. 214; J.S. Also the bed cover raised because of the Virgins legs; Ad [Addendum] Death of Virgin: see R. [Roger Packman Hinks], Caravaggio’s Death of the Virgin, (Charlton lectures on art; 35), London: Oxford University Press], 1953, pp. 10-11.

[recto] [B.] [= René van Bastelaer, Les estampes de Peter Bruegel l'Ancien, Bruxelles: van Oest, 1908, pl.] 116  Death of Virgin. [Zin doorstreept].The painting transformed into graphic work perhaps not in Bruegel's life time (when did Ortelius send the print to Coornhert?). The woman taken in adultery likewise in print after Bruegel's death (1579). In both prints not such a strong chiaroscuro as in painting. If the painting is not by Bruegel it must be by a better artist, for it is better than the print, e.g. the cat different treatment of fire- dogs, more logical in [verso] painting (dark, as seen against the light). The effect of the candle on the table lost in print. Everything more regular and 'accurate' in print, e.g. the left candle at the top in background quite straight in print, leaning to left in painting. Creases in Virgin's [onleesbaar] elaborate and pretty in print (amplified), great sweeps in painting; B. 114. 3) Resurrection a different case, this is done after a drawing, not a painting.
General: Bruegel as painter. Wie bei Dürer bilden Gemälde zum einer Teil seiner Produktion [...][scan]

F.G. In der Landschafts B's. Wie in 'Naer het Leven' Unterscheidung zw[ischen] Einzelaufnahme, die nicht als Komposition gedacht ist und nicht direkt in die Komposition verwendet wird. (panel 39 x 55,5cm) identical with Marlier, Pierre Brueghel le Jeune, 1969, p. 80, Fig. 30 (detail only). The whole picture repr. in the exhib. catal. Prague, Galerie Nat. inv.N° 0-10-151, Fig 33 Le N° 27 (Galerie Nationale de Prague) n'est sûrement pas de Pierre le Jeune et la simplification naïve des formes est proche de la manière d'Abel Grimmer.

Massacre of Innocents. Black yellow staff refers to Imperial Habsburg, as well as the eagle in the Herald's tabbard. It all happened in the Roman Empire of which the Empire of Bruegel's time was a continuation. There is no reference to Spain therefore! In the large flag the in the centre the lion is the lion of Flanders. Terlinden is right with his interpretation as a police expedition.

According to [Charles A.] AUBER, Histoire et theorie du symbolisme religieux [avant et depuis le christianisme, etc, Paris; Poitiers], III, 1884, p. 182, 583 the thistle was a symbol of penitence etc. Quoted in Herbert Friedmann, The Symbolic Goldfinch [Its History and Significance in European Devotioal Art], The Bollingen Series, VII, Pantheon Books (New York), 1946, p. 23, 175. See also L. [Lottlisa] Behling [= Die Pflanze in der Mittelalterlichen Tafelmalerei, Weimar: Böhlaus, 1957] on symbolism of plants and [Ingvar] Bergström.

Good Shepherd. The Good Shepherd gives his life for his herd, according to the gospel, but this is not usually represented. In Bruegel's print of 1565 he is fighting with the wolf, as also in C. Matsys's (?) painting in 1932 with Thomas Harries or in Hans Bol's drawing, but never is this shown being killed by the wolf. H. Bol, 2 drawings in Witt Collection, exh. R&A Flemish & Belgian Art 300-1900, 1927: 535 The Good Shepherd (20,2 x 30 cm); 538 The Hireling Shepherd (20,2 x 30,5 cm) cf. the prints from the Theatrum Biblicum of the same compositions with differences, by M. de Vos, engraved by Goltzius.

Ad [Addendum] Frick: Three Soldiers. There is a comparable group with men in very similar dresses in The Crucifixion, Inv.N° 627, by J.B. in Vienna. A soldier, also seen from the back, in practically the same dress as the drummer, though his-slashed-breeches are a bit broader at the bottom like those a the flute player; to the right of this soldier another, whose dress apart from the last armor is even closer to that of the drummer; he also has an almost identical sword. This second soldier, striding out correspondends to the drummer seen from the front. The drummer's dress also appears in Battle of Arbela (Louvre).

[recto] Ad [Addendum] Bruegel: Way to Calvary. Compositionally close to Bles: Doria Pamphilj and Vienna Akademie. City on the left, Rock in centre, place of execution, surrounded by crowd, on right. Movement of people around the central path, many figures & horses seen from the back and including peddlar with load on his back seen from the back. Women carrying loads on their heads Christ in distance breaking down under the cross [schema] cf. also Corn. Massys, Way to Calvary, Hluboka ([Heinrich Gerhard] Franz, [= Niederländische Landschaftsmalerei im Zeitalter des Manierismus, Graz: Akademische Druck- u[nd] Verlagsanstalt], fig. 114, text p. 95 f.) but from right to left, also peddlar! Children tiny Christ breaking down under cross. Corn. Massys (?) Brussels (Franz, p. 96, fig. 116) with mourners on right, round church Jerusalem, children;
 [verso] For the disposition of the reds see also the Way to Calvary (by the Brunsw[ich] Monogr[ammist]?) in Basel (Franz, Colour pl. 15).[scan]

Correct measurements: to me sent by Mrs. [onleesbaar]: the reproduction in Minkowski and the Hallsborough Catal. incomplete. Town slightly different from Vienna. More at top & sides. The central "Colosseum" parts-brick red, the outer shell grey - lash in transition; [verso] Differences when compared with Vienna. The tower moved further back (losing much of its impact). The foreground figures smaller and there is a great deal of space (filled with reduction figures which do not fit the subject) between these foreground group and the tower.

[Max J.] Friedländer [= Die altniederländische Malerei], XIV, [Leiden: Sijthoff's], 1937 citaten pp. 30, 31, 61; [blad 2] Bauernhochzeit Detroit. F.G. gegenüber dem Van der Heyden Stich (B. 210) ein genaue erhöh[un]g der Tieferwirk[un]g, Brauttisch ganz tief eingesetzt (typisch spät). Hier beginnt Bruegel mit dem Rhythmus der Überschnerdigen der Tanzenden Paare zu arbeiten. Die Vordergrund motive z.T. dieselber wie B. 210, aber welche Steigerung der Wirkung durch die Kette der gehoben Arme, die in die Tiefe zum Tisch führt. In Wiener Bauerntanz die Idee weiter geführt ohne erhöhter [onleesbaar].

Connections between Bosch & Bruegel in Vienna Last Judgment: 1) Rebel Angels; 2) Central picture-composition: Proverbs (Stridbeck); 3) Many details of Hell in centre recur in drawings of Deadly Sins (examine in detail); 4) Last Judgment above cf. drawing of Last Judgment: the grouping of figures; 5) Ira (Baldass 1959, pl. 44)[= Hieronimus Bosch, Wien: Schroll, 1959] group of soldiers, one with helmet, cf. Bruegel: Fall of Rebel Angels.

Harbour of Naples. The solution to the problem of the round jetty of Naples Harbour, which in fact was not round, is probably to be found in the fact that Bruegel was not interested so much in the actual view, but, in the Strait of Messina, in the sea battle which he also showed in the print van Bastelaer 96 (Lebeer, N° 40) and that he took over for the painting thus circular jetty of Messina. He must have made drawings of both places (the one of Reggio opposite Messina (Münz, N° 26) has survived in R'dam). The presentation of the ships in both the engraving (published 1561) cf. the series of Boats; [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'very important: Lebeer's text on the boats.'
Svetlana Alpers, Bruegel's festive peasants, in: Simiolus 6 (1972/73) (appeared Fall, 1974); [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'For Fritz Grossmann in admiration Svetlana Alpers.'

BAARD, Willem van de Velde de Oude, Willem van de Velde de Jonge, Amsterdam, Palet serie), 1942, p. 4, cf. also Hendrick Cornelisz. Vroom, Return from the 2nd expedition to East India (9 July 1599) (A'dam, Rijksmuseum, repr. ibidem, n° 7); [kantlijn] Also in the English 'Platts' see [Erna] Auerbach on Volpe in Burl.Mag.[92, (1950)].

Bauerntanz, Wien. F.G. zur Deutung. Die Leute gehen sich der Lustbarkeit [onleesbaar] (Ira) Küssen (Luxuria) Trinken (Gula). Narr- natürliche Triebe  im Menschen schon im kleinen Kind(irre) in der Kinderspielen benehmen sich die Kinder wie Erwachsene kopieren Erwachsenen konstratiert mit Kirche: die Kirche erscheint über das Torrendes die Kompositionlinien führen auf sie zu rechts im Heiligenbild am Baum links der Fahne mit Heiligen. Hier sind die [onleesbaar] der Religion aber die Menschen gehen sich ihrens sundigen Triebe leben hin. Anderseits in Elster am Galgen sie leben ihr vergugtes Leben ohne zu bedenken. [onleesbaar] unbedachtes Wort sie an den Galgen und der Friedhof bringt.[scan]

[recto] St John the Baptist Preaching. 1) In Italian Gothic Art & Renaissance John shows Christ to the Crowd e.g. architrave of main door of Pisa Baptistery, XIII C.; 2) Andrea Pisano in Baptistery door Florence; 3) Baptistery Mosaic, Florence; 4) Florence, Opera del Duomo. Embroidery cycle of Life St. John after Ant. Pollaiuolo St. John points to Christ (with whom are two apostles); 5) Bozen [= Bolzano], S. Giovanni in Villa ([Antonio]  Morassi, [Storia della] pittura nella Venezia tridentina [dalle origini alla fine del quattrocento, Roma: Libreria dello Stato, 1934], p. 206); 6) Ghirlandaio, S. Maria Novella; 7) Sarto, Scalzo. On the other hand there are as well sermons of St. John without Christ; [verso] Flemish Art: And looking upon Jesus as he walked, he saith: 'Behold the Lamb of God' John, I, 36: 1) School of D. Bouts, Berlin, K.F.M. [=Kaiser Friedrich-Museums] (copy after Prince Ruprecht picture, but the donor replaced by six people listeners to St. John; 2) Schongauer School, Colmar Museum, ex church at Tempelhoff, near Bergheim-upper-Rhine: panel on right St. George & Dragon on left crowd around St. John who points to Christ: from St. John's mouth [onleesbaar] words: Ecce agnus Dei...[sic] Christ like a ghost like figures walking past like in Bouts.[scan]

Fall of Rebel Angels. The subject occurs e.g. in Book of Hours of Mary of Burgundy by Master of Mary of Burgundy in Berlin Print Room (MS 78B12, Pächt, Pl. 39a), c. 1482-quite differently treated before Dürer!): One great Angel with cross staff, on the ground, overcoming angels fleeing to the left into a gate (gate of hell?). In the air in the distance and in the background some winged daemons; Bruegel & Dürer (Occupation with Dürer around 1562) several motifs from the Apocalypse used in Fall of Rebel Angels, Triumph of Death (Resurrection also after Dürer). [recto] Im Katalog der Ausstellung der Münchener Pinakothek in der National Gallery 1949 ist bei Bruegel's Schlaraffenland (N° 29) folgende Deutung gegeben: The scholar lying on his doctor's gown, the peasant on his flail and the soldier on a cushion, represent sluggards from three classes of society. Perhaps to be interpreted as a satire on the apathy of the people under Alva's rule. 
Weisst Du, bitte, woher diese Deutung stammt? Sie findet sich nicht im Pinakothek-Katalog von 1936 [= Ältere Pinakothek München, München: Carl Gerber, 1936], soll aber im Katalog der Amsterdamer Ausstellung schon vorkommen;  [verso] Oder soll [onleesbaar] im Katalog der Austellung Masterpieces from the Alte Pinakothek Munich, London, Nat.Gallery 1949, N° 29) vorgeschlagen wird die Apathie des Volkes unter Albas Schreckensherrschaft [onleesbaar]stelt werden: Look up [Charles de] Tolnay [= Pierre Bruegel l'Ancien : I : texte : II : planches, Bruxelles: Nouvelle société d'éditions],1935.

[recto] Tolnay. Newly Discovered Miniatures by Pieter Bruegel the Elder, Burl. Mag., CVII, 1965, p. 110f. Towneley Lectionarium. Fig. 3 Stormy Harbour  4 x 7cm from Towneley Lectionary, f° 23, Public Libray, New York. Here sky treatment like in Dr. Becker's painting. p. 110 The relationship of this early miniature to Bruegel's work is obvious. It is sufficient to refer to its close connection with the earliest known painting by the master, the Landscape with Sailing Boats and a Burning Town, in a private collection (3) F. GROSSMANN, The Paintings of P. Bruegel the Elder, N° 1 (1955), cat.n° 1, in which the two sailing ships in the centre foreground are almost identical with the two in the left foreground p. 113 of the tiny Bruegel miniature, p. 113 Miniature done in Rome 1553; M. Levi d'Ancona, Illuminati by Clovio Lost & Found, Gaz.B.Arts, 1950, p. 55 very detailed study of Towneley Lectionarium. She dates the Last Judgment miniature hypothetical after 1561; [verso] Webster Smith in MA thesis, Inst. of Fine Arts, New York Univ. (1951) dated the Lectionary between 1550 & 1560.

Ad [Addendum] Treulosigkeit der Welt. Dass der [onleesbaar] durch die Welt kommen sich in der Welt krümmt im Sinnbild der Feinds ist, ist klar aus der Radierung Wendelin Dietterlin's d.Ä. Der Auferstehende Christus Tod und Sünde überwindet (Schrade, Auferstehung, Abb. 151).

Bruegel: Triumph of Death. The torture stakes and gallows top right very close to the same motif top left in 'Hell Scene with Tortures' (based on  'Last Judgment') by a Bosch Follower, (panel, 62 x 56 cm, Sale Brussels, Palais des Beaux-Arts, 19-21 June, 1956. Nancy Dyke includes this picture in her 'Workshop A' (Bosch Imitators, c. 1515-1520), but this may be too early [= Nancy Dyke Corwin, The Fire Landscape: Its Sources and Its Development from Bosch Through Jan Brueghel I : with Special Emphasis on the Mid-Sixteenth Century Bosch "Revival", Ph.D. Thesis Univ. of Washington, Ann Arbor, 1980]. Ad [Addendum] Problems around Bruegel. The fact that the majority of prints after Bruegel bears Latin texts speaks for connection with humanists. But there is a number of prints with French and/or Flemish inscriptions. One would have to draw up lists of the various kinds to establish the significance of the use of the various languages.

[recto] Ad [Addendum] Flight into Egypt (A.S.). Ernst Cohn-Wiener, Baroda Picture Gallery. Catalogue of European Pictures, Baroda 1935, p. 13: Marten Ryckaert: 43 The Flight into Egypt. St. Joseph, who as a carpenter has his tools with him and the Virgin Mary in a red mantle sitting on a donkey with the Child Christ, are travelling through a spacious landscape. A heathen image is falling from a wayside shrine, according to one of the Christian legends. The landscape is sharpely detailed in design. All the details of the fields, the rocks, and; [verso] the houses and fortification of the city in the background are perceptible. This city gives us a good picture of a Northern European fortified town of the 16th century. Signed: 16 MR 30, Oil on wood 16" high by 241/2" wide. (Reproduction in Witt L. under M. RYCKAERT where reference to L. Gassel).

[vouwblad] [recto] Ad [Addendum] Bruegel: Return of Herd; An Autumn picture: In Stchavinskiy Collection [Sobranie kartin V.A. Shchavinskago = Collection W. Stchawinsky], Petrograd ,1917], 'N° 77, C.[Cornelis] Massys' (Witt Library under C. Matsys) which certainly is not by C. Massys, but early XVII, with a diagonal river landscape on the right & developed from Bruegel, appear several Autumn motifs (August-Sept.-Oct. or Sept.-Oct.-Nov.?[sic] On left [onleesbaar] picking apples, left foreground people with grapes in baskets. In central middle ground: sower. In right foreground turned towards right bottom corner: Herd of cattle being driving home by man on white horse, dressed exactly like in Bruegel with; [verso] hat of the same type, brim in front turned up and with a Heeveless 'Kapuze'. He holds a long pole in his gloved right hand. In front of him a man on foot with a long steel driving the cattle, at his side a smaller one (a young boy?[sic], walking with his long stick [onleesbaar].The picture is not copied from Bruegel, but probably inspired by him. The garnements of the cattle drivers in a Flemish picture show that not alpine dress (against Haberlandt!)[= Arthur Haberlandt, 'Das 'Herbstbild' oder 'Die Heimkehr der Herde' Peter Bruegels d.Ä., in: Karl Ilg (Hrsg.), Beiträge zur Volkskunde Tirols. Festschrift für H. Wopfner, 2. Teil, (Schlern-Schriften; 53), Innsbruck: Wagner, 1947-1948]

Photo needed). See Vienna catalogue. High viewpoint. Ships decorative in foreground. The tapestries 1554 Studio Willem Pannemaker, completed, 1546 by Mary of Hungary commissioned to Vermeyen. Among Vermeyen's assistants according to Göbel: P. Coecke van Aelst. The tapestry cartoons in the time of Ernst  & also early XVIII in Brussels; [verso] cf. also another see battle: Messina by Bruegel, Bastelaer 96. Glück, Bruegel and Antiquity, [=Peter Brueghel the Elder and Classical Antiquity, in: Art Quarterly 6 (1943), pp. 167-186) p. 169 considers Bruegel to have been the first to introduce this motif, lent apart from Vermeyen it appears also the N.G.[National Gallery] picture (possibly Bruegel's prototype, but not by Bruegel) before Bruegel.

[2 bladen] [blad 1, recto] Babel Vienne. The Tower placed quite near to us, although the intervening landscape would mean that it is in middleground it is seen at eye level, the town on the other hand, in order to show the multitude of houses, to make it a city, is seen almost in an aerial area. Castle to the right of tower reminiscence of Naples; Babel Beuningen. Horizon much lower than in Vienna. The Tower clearly in middle ground, seems to rise directly in front of us, and above all with the circles stressed and rising from left to right, the impression of the tower turning is very strong all this points to later phase than Vienna; [blad 1, verso] The turning movement also enhanced by clouds. Cloud coming from right in front, cloud on left moving away or behind the tower to the right; [blad 2, recto] 2 Towers of Babel. Composition. [...][blad 2: scan]

[vouwblad] [recto] BM Printroom. Peasant Wedding. Copy from Bruegel (used by Hollar). Pen and wash.  The figure groups in very delicate pen (& wash). The groups in the background on the right partly only in black chalk (greatly faded). The landscape beyond the brook on the left with partly darker in a more coarse pen lines. The castle in the background left- still in the "fine" manner. There is not a river between the trees, the ducks also differ from the painting. Could the drawing being the design for the painting-with the right part copied from P.B.I , the left part added by the designer and then altered in execution of picture; [verso] Can this be a drawing by J.B.? Possible. The Bisschop drawings. Fenwick Catal. p. 176 Bisschop: 1) Dance of Peasants. Popham suggests copy of Spiridon picture or one of its variants; [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. certainly in Spiridon [onleesbaar] with birds missing. It differs also from Detroit by combination of the trees at the top, and above all the cloth behind the bride is hanging from a stiff rod and is quite strange; more complete on left & right than Detroit on the other hand there is more forground in [onleesbaar]; P.B.I The Berlin drawing of the 2 blind men & 1 blind woman copied in a picture by P.B.II. Sale F. Fiévez, Brussels 8.4.30, N° 26, panel 20 x 30 cm (in BM Print room under reproduction of P.B.II).

Bruegel beginnt und endet mit Landschaft, zu der schließlich der Menschkampf. Die Verbindung mit Bosch (1556-1564) eine wenn auch sehr wichtige Zwischenstufe (auch kompostionell wichtig) Bosch führt Bruegel zur menschl. Gestalt 1557. Symbolisches in Sämann noch ohne Bosch. Mittel ausgedruckt, aber schon immer in Zeichnung und Stich [...][scan]

Ad [Addendum] Sermon of St. John. The theme is conversion: There are pagans (Islam: man in turban), jews (Rabby), gipsies [sic], people possessed by demons (epileptic) who all need conversion to true faith- which is Christ. St John is pointing to Christ as the true salvation. On the right, on the sight of Christ, are the adherents of Christ, on the hill, and [onleesbaar] Franciscan monks (seen positively)(and on the right is the Baptism of Christ). If in the group on the hill is a self-portrait, this does not mean Anabaptists, only that these converted to true faith include Bruegel himself. As for epileptic see: Werner DANCKERT, Unehrliche Leute: die verfemten Berufe, Bern, München [Francke], 1963, [citaat] p. 231. As subject of conversion: the Sermon of St. John has its counterpart in the Conversion of St. Paul.[woord onderaan in potlood: onleesbaar]

[recto] Wooded Landscape with 2 Hunters & 3 Dogs (Leegenhoek), panel, 38,5 x 55,5 cm. Landscape type - loo into forestglade - if by P.B.I - anticipating Coninxloo. Comparable to Prague landscape drawing of 1554 (used by Cock)(see Arndt), Drawing Berlin (Münz, N° 24 (recto & verso), but does not show any of the distant river valley view seen from above. Very close character landscape with bears (Brit.Mus. Münz, A 28 (J.B.?) Lugt [1927], Arndt [1972]: copy after P.B. and the engraving (Bast. 16): Pagus Nemorosus also without distant view. The foliage would agree with P.B.I, particularly the little impressionist leaves about the tree trunks, cf. Landscape with tower, San Diego (photograph Putnam 6c). But: the soil in broad horizontal brush strokes, the way the trees on the right are rooted in the ground the painterly form of the bushes tree trunk higher; [verso] centre and of the opening in tree trunk by left edge do not look like P.B. - The firm bottom right corner more like in Temptation Washington (though trees different); A beautiful picture - with the light breaking through the forest (cf. Rubenspatches of forest interess[ant]; The owl in the tree in left edge not very P.B. like - the dogs also different. Could this be J.B. after P.B.? or in the manner of P.B? Some of the trees too straight for P.B.; Brown of tree trunks dominates, (kind of underpainting like P.B. & Rubens); some impressionists green foliage (with impasto); man in centre with crimson jacket - white preparation, thin original panel covered by new cradling panel; left man has spear pointing down; right man has spear pointing upwards to left; 2 white and one brown [onleesbaar], brown goat at root of 3 rd curved tree from right ; 2nd tree from right: roots is pattern on surface, not growing out of soil, as P.B. Generally too much decorative pattern; Trees in the distance in middle-green, look like J.B.
Ill. Kinderspelen

Tower of Babel. Tower of Babel  by Hendrick van Cleve at [Kunsthalle] Hamburg (1525-1580) (Photo Witt Library) When exactly was he in Italy? When was this picture painted? The Tower is round near a river, a Roman triumphal arch in front of it, classical details. In the foreground men working at stones like Bruegel, Vienna. It all looks more like based on Bruegel than the other way around.

The year 1556 marks a change: from that year on for many years to come man dominates Bruegel's not man as the athletic figure of motion art but man as a moral being. Although he does not cease to before his removal to Brussels man not seen as the human figure in the Italian sense.

Better than Birmingham; B) Roundel, diam. 161/2", Cotton Hall, Derbyshire. Seen at Agnew's, 16-6-76. Oak panel. Looks better than the roundel of Enschede-better than P.B.II, but doubtful whether by J.B. greatly rubbed. The circular eyes of the Birmingham copy seem to indicate that the original was a work by P.B.I. Marlier is wrong in assuming that the lost original was a work of M. van Cleve, but it is possible that he painted the Birmingham copy.

Bruegel: Peasant Wedding's. Drawing at Besançon, exhibited: Paris: Musée des arts décoratifs, Besançon le plus ancien Musée de France, Février-Avril 1957. Dessins Bruegel (Pierre le Vieux) (attribué à), citaat p. 59, nr. 121 Paysans conversant (Planche XXXIV [...]; [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. the collector's mark is not E. Desperet (Lugt 721) but Lugt 1440 Jules Dupan (unless there is some alteration in Lugt supplement); F.G. clearly the five figures are copied out of a Bruegelesque Wedding composition. There are 5 figures in the centre a group of three, which agrees with the three figures on the extreme right of the Hollar drawing in Bastelaer 212, Parthey 597, the B.M. (Popham, Pl. XLVII, N° 12) of the figure on the right is different. (In addition there are in the Descamps drawing various objects: a ladder, a crossbow, a bowl, hand bells [beschadigd]. Such a group of three in somewhat similar arrangement, but differs greatly in details in Detroit in right background; [verso] The two other figures in Besançon clearly point to a dance picture, both seen from the back-none so far found directly in a picture: 1) The one on the left can be compared with a man seen from back on left in Detroit  2) altitude of dancer seen from back in the same position as the woman in the left couple in Detroit. The drawing perhaps by Jan B. or after a composition by Jan B.  - or are these 'dancers' copied from a lost picture by P.B.I?  Look up Jan Bruegel Windsor. Also look up drawing Oxford, Follower of Bruegel 31 Peasants dancing 4 couples ...[sic] the couple in centre forground is seen from the back; [vastgehecht: tekening in potlood door FG met inscriptie] Besançon Inv. D.2.
Woman taken in Adultery. The man in the right very close to the man in the same place in Andrea del Sarto's Scalzo Fresco (repr. Wölfflin, Classic Art, Phaidon fig. 109, p. 162) [...][scan]

[recto] PEASANT WEDDING in open air. The composition combining motifs from Beekeepers (Berlin drawing) in the landscape with motifs from Wedding Dance in the Open Air from Van der Heyden's print (Bast. 210) - partly revised, partly in the same sense, with group of 3 men added on right (like the Besançon drawing) and group of 7 figures added on left (like in B[uda]pest drawing) seems to be a pasticcio by Jan Brueghel, of which a very fine version, in my view by Jan B. appeared in anonymous sale at Christie's 1 April, 1960, N° 105 (panel, 14 x 21 in.)(as P.B.I). The drawing in the B.M. (Catal. Popham, p. 146, N°12, pl. XLVII, 12) which was used by Hollar for his etching (Parthey 597, Bast. 212), repr. Dostal, pl. 36) is a not too exact copy of the picture (with e.g. the figure across the water on the left missing) on th other hand the picture does not have the "phallic" presentations of the man. A drawing by Bisschop (after a picture in the Arundel Coll. Feste de contadini in aguazzo??[sic]) in B.M. after Arundel picture to be looked up. Literature: Bastelaer, Estampes, N° 212 (but cf. also 210, 211, 213) Bastelaer-Hulin de Loo, p. 84, n. 1: Le dessin des Danseurs de Noce au British Museum [...]; [verso] [...] Popham, Catal. Drawings, B.M., 1932, p. 146f., N° 12, pl. XLVII; Glück, 1951, N° 56.

The landscape looks rather poor. The attrib. to Bruegel very doubtful couldn't it be an attempt by Clovio to imitate Northern landscapes? Tolnay does not give the inv.N° of the MS. Look up the volume at the museum; [verso] Nothing about the colours used. Like Benesch T. tried to rush into print. The miniature is very inferior to the earliest known drawings of Bruegel.

Joseph Alexander RACZYNSKI, Die flämische Landschaft vor Rubens : Beiträge zur Entwicklungsgeschichte der flämischen Landschaftsmalerei in der Zeit von Brueghel bis zu Rubens, Frankfurt am Main [Prestel], 1937, citaten p. 65: Tobias Verhaeght ...van Mander aus dem Lehrgedicht (cap. 8 über die Landschaft]; [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. cf. Paulus Sturz!; [verso] p. 66 [...] [toegevoegde vermelding]: F.G. Verhaeght ganz besonders von Bruegel abhängig in das Gebirglandscahft von 1612 (München) die auf Stiche der grossen Landschaftserie von der Art Magdalena poenitens (Bastelaer 8) oder 'Solicitude Rustica' (Bastelaer 12) zurückgeht. Wenn man sieht, wie sehr Verhaeght von Bruegel abhängig ist und wie bedeutend die Erfindung, dann sehr wahrscheinlich dass das Lugt Bild ein der 'Erfindung' auf Bruegel basiert.'
Entwicklung nicht wie Friedländer [...][scan]

Bruegel. Death of Virgin. There seems to be some connection with Dirck Crabeth's window of the Death of the Virgin in Oude Kerk, A[mster]dam. Drawing in Rijkprentenkabinet see [Otto Benesch, Zu van Regteren - Altenas van Gheyns Monographie], [Die] Graphische Künste, 1937, II/4, p. 144 [143-146] & [I.Q. van] Regteren Altena, [= Teekeningen van Dirck Crabeth] in Oud Holland, LV, 1938, p. 107-114 - What is the date of Crabeth's design? There are only the 12 apostles around the bed (a 4 poster with curtains) but St. Peter supporting the candle,  halo by Mary (who is lying back already dead?) the theory of the grisailles - the silhouette of the standing apostle at the foot of the bed have something in common with Bruegel's composition. The bed is parallel to the picture plane and three are in effects of light & dark - although then the same clouds at the top of the composition.

Woman taken in Adultery. Bruegel's painting, or more probably the print after it was the inspiration for Rembrandt's drawing in Stockholm, National Museum, [Otto] Benesch, The Drawings of Rembrandt, vol. V, 1957, N° 1038 (fig. 1253) as already noticed by Benesch (p. 217): 'In the present drawing he (= Rembrandt) chose the incident of Christ writing his reply in the sand (perhaps inspired by the engraving after Bruegel, Bastelaer III, as Rijckevorsel correctly observed). On the two later ones, Nos. 1047 (Munich, Graphische Sammlung) and 1046 (Cologne, Wallraf-Richartz Museum): [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G.: Although Christ in these two latter drawings is shown standing. The wall of people formed by the crowd may still owe something to the Bruegel composition.'

Here is Hell with representations of Sins and Sinners - to be deciphered with help of the drawings for the Seven Deadly Sins: 1) Toad for Avaritia; 2) The monster [horn?] foreshortened showing anus in front of the naked couple, and this couple underneath the harp tower - for Luxuria; 3) The monster with spoon in anus and bord in hand - for Gula (in the drawing on the right - the combination of the motifs is somewhat difficult); 4) The bird underneath the Gula monster with a plucked peacock (for Superbia) as [...] the from Luxuria; 5) Is there a bear for Ira?; 6) ~ a turkey for Invidia; 7) [Anything?] (snail) for Desidia.[scan]

Art Institute of Chicago. Blind[?]. The paintings in Vienna (Baldass 1917, fig. 7 [= Ludwig Baldass, Unbekannte Bilder in Wien und Budapest, in: Jahrbuch des kunsthistorischen Instituts 11 (1917), pp. 1-15] and Basle N° 140, attributed by Baldass to Marten van Cleve (1527-8) differ in several respects from the drawing. The main difference apart from the missing dog & tree trunk and that that the spatial arrangement and background differ is in the first fallen blindman, who in the painting is seen with the legs turned to the spectator (developed from Napels), in the drawing he falls with his head (not visible) to the front and one leg the back. The drawing may be an original design by M. van Cleve (but it differs greatly from the drawing of cripples with fox-tails in Munich) or more likely a drawing by someone else after a lost composition by Bruegel, which inspired M. van Cleve.

Kindermord. Von der Bilder Bruegels, die jetzt in Wien sind, keines [onderstreept] ursprunglich in Prag nachweisbar. Bloss der Paulussturz erscheint 1737 in Prag. Der Kindermord in Wien im Inventar G (zw[ischen] 1612 & 1618). Das Hampton Court Bild wohl identisch mit: Prag 1621: 'Eine Dorfblinderung vom alten Prügel.' Prag 1647-48: 'Eine Dorfblinderung.' Die seltsame Massacre in Prag 1621 erscheint dreifach daher rasche das eine W[iene]r. Bild des Faschings.

[2 vouwbladen][vouwblad 1] Ad [Addendum] 42. BRUEGEL. Versuchung des hl. Antonius (Washington). Joseph Alexander Graf RACZYNSKI, Die Flämische Landschaft vor Rubens, Fkft a. M. [Frankfurt] am Main, 1937, citaat p. 53-53 [...]; [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. Die Zuschreibung an Jan B. wohl berechtigt. Der Baumschlag erinnert zu ihn; die Raumauffassung: Vordergrundlandschaft mit Fernvedute ohne Verbindung sieht nicht sehr nach P.B.I. aus; Wenn von P.B., dann ganz spät, der Baum links erinnert ein wenig an Vogelnest. Das durchleuchtet Wald erinnert am rechten Rand wunderbar -aber ist das P.B.? Ist nicht die Auffassung des Waldes später? Ein verwandte Komposition zeigt die Landschaft mit dem Holzfällern in Dresden von J.B.I (Raczynski, Abb. I sie ist eine Weiterbildung (seiten verkehrt) der Antonius Landschaft. Vordergrundskulisse mit Fernbild; hier der eine Holzfaller aus den Buckinghammer Komposition [?]; [vouwblad 2] Bruegel Ad 42. Temptation of Anthony, Washington; [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. Grave doubts as to B's authorship. The 'handwriting' is different (Beautiful early Jan B.?) The foliage painted in dense sickle shaped strokes which is quite unsual for P.B. The sort of 'Waldweben' on the right a kind of Romantic interpretation of nature alien to him. The summary painting of the main figures also not like P.B. The figures more based on Bosch than on Bruegel, on the other hand nearer to late Bruegel, therefore not an early Boschlike picture by Bruegel. The scene in the sky also clearly based on Bosch. Thin tree [onleesbaar] at first sight looks like late Bruegel, but compared with the thin trees in 'Vogelnest' or Darmstadt, the different technique becomes apparent. There are a few patches of foliage treated in the dotted right 'manner' in the rock. The trees framing the bridge but for the rest the whole technique is different and a little late.[scan]

[recto] Jan Brueghel: Temptation of St. Anthony, Washington. The [onleesbaar] lack the sharp precision of P.B.I. The foliage with its broad strokes is different from the pointillistic one with little dots by P.B. Everything is too 'malerisch'. The gruesome atmosphere of such a scene as it would appear in Bosch and Bruegel completely missing (the scenes in the air inspired by left wing of Bosch's St. Anthony, Lisbon. Jan B. also used Bosch in other pictures e.g. the Prado Adoration). If by P.B.I in which period should it be placed? Certainly it could not be in the 1550s- it can only be underdtood as doubtful from the late (Darmstadt) P.B. and again and again it is the Darmstadt picture echoes of which appear in Jans Brueghel. (This picture must have remained with the family - it had some personal meaning of which Bruegel's widow a mother - in- law must have knowing, also judging by van Mander's account; [verso] The atmospheric effects - the relation between foreground and background also impossible for P.B. - they point to Jan. Perhaps a rather early Jan B. Denucé to be looked up. For the light spot betw[een] the tree cf. the Landscape in Coll. Perman (Klauner, fig. 1).

Mus. drawing for his print b) Jan de Bisschop drawing Br. M. ex Fenwick look up; 3) Duarte 1682 [kantlijn] wohl kam von Arundel; Boerenbruiloft, vol figuren oliverf ...225 gl.[...], Een boeren Kermis vol figuren waterverf, beyde bynaer van een grootte, daer Karel Vermander zijn schilderboek [sic] mentie van maeckt 1676 Constantin Huygens ebenso; 4) Imstenraedt Kremsier, 30 x 42 cm Bauern[onleesbaar] mit 9 Figuren; [verso] wohl ein Bild des jungen P.B. noch sehen! This would account for one of the Arundel pictures. Kermis in Duarte is water colour, not the Wedding Festa di Contadini in Arundel watercolour. There is no picture called "Wedding" in Arundel! cf. Stevens 1668, num. 23 Une Fête villagoise; [verso] Bei Arundel 3 Kompositionen: 1) Festa de Contadini in aquazzo. Inventio di Bruegel; 2) BREUGEL Balla de Contadini; 3) BREUGHEL Festa de Contadini.  2) konnte sein Imstenraedt (75. Un ballo de nove persone) Kremsier 349; 1) vielleicht die Komposition radier von Hollar (B. 597, Bastel. 36) P. BRUEGEL: 'The digging of the Canal between Antwerp and Brussels.' Lost painting (?) only mentioned by Van Mander, see F. Grossmann, Bruegel, The Paintings, p. 20. The picture in the Pulitzer Gallery, certainly XVII C. [later toegevoegd]:(18th Cent.?), may reproduce the lost work, of which perhaps only a drawing existed. The composition would fit in with that of the Winter Landscape with a Bird Trap (1565). The Canal was completed in 1565. Look up [Alexandre] Henne, [Alphonse] Wauters, Histoire de Bruxelles. Baedeker, Belgien, 1930, p. 112 Schon seit der Mitte des XVI. Jh. war Brüssel mit dem Rupel, einem Nebenfluss der Schelde, auf dem ? bemerken sind, durch dem 28km langen und 3,2 m tiefen Kanal von Willebroeck verbunden [...]; [verso] p. 119 [...]; p. 170 [...]; What towns appear on the right: Mechelen, Antwerp or Brussels? The canal built between Brussels & Willebroeck. Can one see Antwerp from there? If one is the cathedral tower of Antwerp what is the other? Malines? In order to show the achievement of joining Antwerp to Brussels-Bruegel must have tried to show that Antwerp was visible from the canal. The right tower really looks like that of Antwerp Cathedral. The left one would be what?  Many tents (for the labourers!). The church on the left is probably old Walpurgis church, destroyed 1798.To be looked up: Old views of Antwerp. A.J.J. Delen, Iconographie van Antwerpen, [Brussel: L.J. Kruyn], 1930; A.H. Cornette, Iconographie van Antwerpen, [De Sikkel], 1935 [= 1933]. See also catal. Paris, Bibl. Exh. Anvers Ville de Flandre et de Rubens, 1954, pl. 6.
[Bibliotheekformulier: British Museum] [Hanns] Bohatta, Bibl. [Bibliographie] der Breviere 1501-1850, [Leipzig: Hiersemann], 1937.

Ad [Addendum] Bruegel: Suicide of Saul. A drawing by Hans Bol, signed and dated 1568, Basel, Küpferstichkabinett (repr. [Heinrich Gerhard] Franz, [Hans Bol als Landschaftszeichner],  Jb.des Kh.Institutes der Univ. Graz [= Jahrbuch des Kunsthistorischen Institutes der Universität Graz], I, 1965, [pp. 19-67], pl. 46, developed from Bruegel. The group of Saul & his shield bearer (?) large in left foreground. On the right the armies with many figures, but background landscape - Weltlandschaft with high mountains follows Patinir & Mathijs Cock tradition rather than Bruegel. Generally in many early Bol drawings,  i.e. before [onleesbaar], trees like in the 'bear' drawings; Ad [Addendum] Months. Drawing by Hans  Bol, signed and dated 1570 in Louvre, Cabinet des dessins, Inv.N° 20908, repr. Franz, Jb.des Kh.Institutes der Univ. Graz, I, 1965, pl. 57. According to Franz representing 2 months: Sept. & October (Look up Lugt in Louvre Catal.) Bol, Seasons, each time with 3 months, and their zodiac signs. Allegorical figure in center. Hermitage, Franz adest plates 101c-101d, text p. 63 designed for engravings by J. Sadeler, date 1580 (Hollstein, III, p. 54, Nos. 228-231, In Winter (pl. 101d) Pisces, Aquarius, Ram, [onleesbaar] of boar at end under Ram.
Pächt Text fehlt.

[recto] Seen at Agnew's but belonging to a family at Cotton Hall, Derbigshire (Mrs. Yeats-Brown) daughter of last owner of Cotton Hall). Peasants tying Faggots (Roundel). A very good version of Marlier, p. ...[sic] The ground partly painted in brown with some dots-imitation of Bruegel. Rubens technique, but actually imitation of it, not forming an underlying layer of brown etc. Fat Man on left in red trouses, lean man on right in blush green trouses & jacket. The left man well dressed, the thin man in rags. The black cap (partly, but not ?) pointillistic. The grey jacket of the fat man and the trouses of the right man partly transparent now. so that ground now partly visible (Bruegel technique); [verso] The outlines of the figures partly drawn in dark colour, but no pentimenti. The man on the ladder with blue jacket. Apart from some rubbing in rather good condition. XIX C. frame, oak panel. On back part of Christie stencil ..SSID... still visible. Composition fits nicely into roundel: originally intented for such. The Birmingham rectangular version for this reason alone would speaks against copy after the lost original. Not in Marlier.
