[recto] Bruegel: Woman Taken in Adultery. Partly indebted to woodcut of the same subject in [Christoph] Froschauer's German bible by Heinrich Vogtherr, Zürich, 1545, (repr. James STRACHAN, Early Bible Illustrations. [A Short Study Based on Some Fifteenth and Early Sixteenth Century Printed Texts], Cambridge [University Press], 1957, fig. 94 (see text of Strachan, p. 57f.). This Bible to be looked up for other subjects as well, e.g. Wise & Foolish Virgins, B.M. C. 18.c.3. Bruegel borrowed from Vogtherr the unsual group of the soldiers on the right and among them in particular the first one; [verso] walking towards the [sic], turning his head towards the centre & looking back. The lower part of the Christ armour of Vogtherr's first soldier reappears (slightly altered) in Bruegel's second soldier.

Marlier, P.B.II, p. 275) signed and dated, according to Marlier, p. 276, P. BREVGHEL 1630. In letter from Karling, 30-5-73, the signature and date are given as P. Breugel 1626. According to Karling recent cleaning has revealed underneath this the signature "BRUEGEL" and below this the date MDLXV..; [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. But is this really a work of P.B.I? There are several factors which speak against Bruegel and rather for Martin van Cleve: 1) The open heath with its perspective appears in the Unfaithful Shepherd and it is unlikely that Bruegel simply repeated the background from another picture, unless one assumes the other way round that the Stockholm picture is an original & the background was copied in the Shepherd, where, however, it makes much more sense in connection with the fleeing figure. The copy in the Vienne Kh. Mus. has a different background.. The signature and date "P.BREVGHEL 1558 appear, according to Marlier p. 276 on the Liechtensteinversion; 2) The Soldier attacking the woman with his foot is taken over from Bruegel's Massacre of the Innocents-again it; [verso] is not likely that Bruegel repeated himself, though it is sure there are differences between these two figures; 3) This figure shows the heave thick - set form of many of M. van Cleve's  later figures; 4) The young peasant - in his final features unlike Bruegel - has parallels in M. van Cleve's more ideal figures owing from his 'Floris' period; The figure group, with the soldier on the left attacking with a spear and the woman on the right is echoed in a drawing by Jacob de Gheyn II, 'a Landscape with robbers', signed and dated 1603, Munich, Staatliche Graphische Slg. (repr. J.G. van Gelder's: De Schoonheid van ons Land. Prenten en tekeningen, Amsterdam 1958, pl. 24). See also Munich Catalogue by Wegner [= Wolfgang Wegner, Die niederländischen Handzeichnungen des 15.-18. Jahrhunderts, 2 dln.,München1973]

Mus. Vienna, where it was first attributed to Bruegel himself: It is almost entirely a landscape in daylight, with a big [onleesbaar]-land occupying most of the space same sailing boats in the slightly ? water and a few buildings in the distant background. [vouwblad] Ad [Addendum] Bruegel. Sermon of St. John. Bruegel reverses the earlier order: Baptism of Christ as main scene, Sermon of St. John as auxiliary as it is found in earlier paintings e.g. in G. David's, Bruges or Patinir, Vienna. In David's Sermon also orientals, though not gypies (?). Oriental costumes also in Patinir's painting (turbans) whereas usually in biblical scenes at this time oriental character not stressed.

[recto] Ad [Addendum] Tax Collectors etc., also Bruegel: Way to Calvary. An old flemish proverb quoted by I. [Ingvar] Bergström, Dutch Still-Life Painting in the Seventeenth Century, London [Faber & Faber], 1956, p. ? [= p. 7] 'Een wockeraar, een molenaar, een wisselaar en een tollenaar zijn de vier evangelisten van Lucifaar' (A usurer, a miller, a money changer, and a tax-collector are the four Evangelists of Lucifer). See the mill in Procession to Calvary and in Gula.
Larry Silver, Q. Massys, Harvard Diss. 1974, p. 249, n. 42: 'The miller is the only unusual member of the four professions cited, but grain merchants had become massive speculators in the early 16th C., and they exploited local shortages. 
These men; [verso] were frequently subject to attack during the urban bread riots of the century. 
Cf. H.G. Koenigsberger and G.L. Mosse, Europe in the Sixteenth Century, N.Y. [= London: Longmans], 1968, p. 23ff. In addition to this book there are general surveys of European economic developments in: F. [ Frédéric] MAURO, Le XVIe siècle européen, aspects économiques, (Nouvelle Clio, N° 32), Paris [Presses Universitaires de France], 1970; [Edwin E. Rich, Charles H. Wilson], The Economy of Expanding Europe in the Sixteenth & Seventeenth Centuries, [Cambridge Economic History of Europe, IV], Cambridge  [Cambridge University Press], 1967.

[recto] Magpie probably stayed in family, it was bequeathed to wife by Bruegel, and when Jan B. wrote to Borromeo he could not find any pictures for the cardinal, he probably did not want to part with the one, as it meant so much to him.(x) Artistically only hardly, becaus eof its meaning but grisaille and the Magpie were 'pauvreté' pictures. (x) Here I have to amend note 47 in Burl.Mag. 1952, p. 229; [verso] Great influence of Magpie on Gallows on Jan Brueghel compositionally again and again. Particularly interesting the picture of Jan (Thiery, pl. 45) when not only the background is reminiscent of the Darmstadt picture but: on the left there is a gallow with a magpie on it.

[recto] In favour: Difference of eyes, the left one round. Technique to be studied. The surface coarser than Munich woman, but hair looks good, cf. Blind Man, pl. 151. Does Bruegel ever paint such a  "(\*) mouth line" technique. Isn't the form too simple compared with e.g. pl. 137. (\*) cf. [onleesbaar] in pl.130. Colour of background like in the Munich Head. For the mouth line, cf. King left border in London Adoration & painter in the Albertina drawing, T. 118.; [verso]The background more brown grey than in repr. A system of pink lines up cheek.The shadows in cross hatchings very fine like with feather in brown ink.[scan]

Budweis), with the group of the Virgin & St. John isolated in foreground on the right. The connection between the Brussels Cornelis Massys & Bruegel also noticed by G.M. in Cat. of exh. Le siècle de Bruegel 1963, p. 123, N° 103 and by E. de CALLATAY, Cornelis Massys paysagiste...[= Cornelis Massys paysagiste, collaborateur de son père et de son frère et auteur de l'Album Errera], Bull.Mus.R. des B.-A. de Belgique, XIV, 1965, [pp. 49-70] p. 69-.

[recto] Good Shepherd. Further argument in favour of P.B.I. The picture is clearly not a copy, as the underdrawings proves. It cannot be the invention of P.B.II, nor does it look like an invention of J.B. The bold invention and the idea can only be by P.B.I As it is not a copy, it is obvisiously the work of P.B.I. The construction of the head, the treatment of the hair comparable to the blind men in Napels. Trousers up with trousers of second from right. There is some similarity in technique ([onleesbaar] nose) of the head of Bailleur in Brussels Museum, but the Bailleur has a heaviness which is absent in shepherd; The incompleteness of white sheep against tree probably due to overcleaning. It is complete in the copy.; Sheep in background of Misanthrope (my Bruegel, 2nd ed., pl. 145), more painterly, but if, cow in Return of Herd (pl. 105); Shepherd's bag very similar to that of Peasant in Bird Nester; [verso] (my Bruegel, 2nd ed. pl. 144), though execution may be by J.B.; Philadelphia 'Unfaithful Shepherd' In trousers, sleeves, distant trees with undistinct character contrasting with Kronacker picture and clearly recognizable as copy; The same shepherd's staff in Faithful and Unfaithful Shepherd - but different in function. In Philadelphia [onleesbaar] down to left, increasing the effect of flight and going across the body. In Good Shepherd leading upwards and  [onleesbaar] composition  [onleesbaar] The composition of the figures -attitude of arms and legs - complementary - in Philadelphia open (the running motif decisive) in Kronacker closed.

Bruegel: Sermon of St. John. This is a combination of 2 subjects Sermon of St. John (Matth. III, 1-12; Mark, I, 4-8, Luke, III, 3-18) & 'Ecce Agnus Dei' (John, I, 29-37). In the background of Gerard David's Baptism of Christ (Bruges) the two scenes are separated, in background Patenier's Vienna Baptism of Christ sermon and the in the distance Christ which can be compared with Bruegel.

[recto] Dr. Becker's Landscape. Brown rock, on left, next to it the whole area of ground green in broad patches. Top left corner greenish. Left[onleesbaar] ship brown with red man in circle. Right large ship grey sail with yellow red fire. In centre above third ship with whitish sail great yellow area extending into sky changing into red, on left top surrounded by bluish sky, and mirrored  yellow in water, all this very painterly. Another great, slightly darker yellow cloud (from fire) on right. Town dark brown. The shore on the right green with some yellow reflections. Foreground bottom right corner rock dark brown. In right bottom corner horizontal reddish brush strokes later addition; [verso]The broad treatment generally speaks against early Bruegel. There is lack of sharp definition of the rocks. There are broad straight brushstrokes over the sails with disregard for curves. Cradled. The panel is encased in such a way that it is not possible to see the original edge. The X-ray shows a horizontal crack c. 7 cm from the top, which would agree with the Lucerne picture, there seems to be some indication of a human figure bottom right, but not exactly by the border as it should be if we [sic]

Triumph des Todes. [Jan] Denucé, [= Inventare von Kunstsammlungen zu Antwerpen im 16. und 17. Jahrhundert, (Quellen zur Geschichte der flämischen Kunst; 2), Antwerpen: De Sikkel, 1932] Valckenisse 1614, [II], p. 23 Triumphe vanden Doot, van Bruegel.

[recto] Bruegel: Landschaft de Boer. N. 1.  Komposition mit Felsen[onleesbaaar] links und rechts (links der höhere Felsen) sehr nahe des Psyche Radierungen 1553 (B.1) aber in der Radierung alles mehr zurückgeschoben. Noch mit das Diagonalschema. Sondern im Patinier vertikaler Flusslauf: Schiff Kulisse vorne noch z. T. unbeholft und sehr früh 1553 cf. Clovio Schiff[onleesbaaar] JUngste Gericht (New Public Library][...]; [verso] Das Meer vorne dunkel, hinter hell wie in Patinier's '[onleesbaar]' und in der Berufung Petri von 1553 ebenso noch beim Icarus. The attributes of Fides painting to the Passion and the Resurrection of the Christ are unique, as unique as the addition of the scenes showing Faith in action, but harder to explain. The attributes refer to three central facts of Christ to three [onleesbaar] the suffering of Christ, his crucifixion, and his victory of death.

The painting attrib. by Glück to M. van Cleve is in the same sense as the drawing, but whereas the engraving (v.B. 205) is reversed it follows the drawing exactly, while the painting differs greatly in many details: [toegevoegde vermelding]: 'F.G. It is not at all certain whether the painting is by M. van Cleve. Treatment of space different and many additional and different figures, compositional changes. The Team of horses and man on the front horse, his position (head turned inwards) closer to Albertina drawing of team of horses (pl. 105).

Good Shepherd by Bruegel 1565 Typical example of 1568 (chapter) : 1) composition & [?] source Raphael: Adoration; 2) Reminiscence of Bosch's Prado Adoration or one of its many copies; 3) Erhard Schön: woodcut - contrast here the shepherd does not carry the lamb on his shoulders; 4) This motive may be derived from Early Christian art (Look up Real Lexikon).

When in England in 1571 he acquires antique statuettes, vases, coins.

MS 34294): At the direction of Margaret of Austria Horenbout painted 16 miniatures & 2 borders in this late 15th century Milanese MS (Hours of Bona Maria Sforza, widow of Galeazzo Maria Sforza) which was in Margaret's collection, 2 of the Flemish additions are dated, one 1579, the other 1520. Hulin (Annuaire des Musées & des Beaux-Arts II, 1939, pp. 16-18, assigned the addiditions to Gerard Horenbout; Motifs used by Bruegel: 1) Falling snow in December picture of Vienna MS 2706 (Hortulus Animae, c. 1510-1520) by Dornhöffer in 2 vols. 1907-11; 2) choppy sea in February Munich cod. lat. 23638 (Book of Hours, early XVI, Simon Bening) see G. [Georg] Leidinger, Miniaturen aus Handschriften der Kgl. Hof- und Staatsbibliothek in München 1912; 3) [onleesbaar] in February Grimani Breviary [scan].

[recto] Neu 22. Bruegel. Kreuztragung. Der vom Rücken gesehene Krämer mit dem Korb am Rücken erscheint schon in einer Kreuztrag[un]g im Palazzo Doria, die dort Lucas Gassel zugeschrieben wird, die aber Puyvelde, La peinture flamande à Rome, Bruxelles 1950, p. 86, dem Herri met de Bles gibt (abgeb. bei Puyvelde Pl. 27). Puyvelde bemerkt: Il existe plusieurs répliques de ce 'Portement de Croix', où à différentes reprises le paysage est changé; l'une est à l'Académie de Vienne, une autre à la Coll. Stuyck del Bruyère d'Anvers, une autre encore a été vendue avec la Coll. Oscar Bondy; [verso] New York, le 3 mars 1949 (richtig) / zitieren! Das Exemplar der Wiener Akademie von Herri met de Bles signiert mit Käuzchen (Katal. 1948, N° 24 u. Abb.7) vgl. dazu Glück: Jan v. Amstel (Aus drei Jhdert. p. 150) von der Beliebtheit des Meisters (= Jan v. Amstel) zeigen zahlreiche Kopien u. Nachahmungen [...] von dieser machte wir nur eine besonders hervorheben: die Landschaft mit Kreuztragung Christi von Herri met de Bles in der Wiener Akademie (bezeichnet mit dem Käuzchen. Hier hat Bles die Figuren frei nach dem Bilde des Braunschweiger Monogrammisten in Palazzo Doria kopiert und auch die übrigen Landschaften Bles beweisen dass er die Bilder des Braunschweiger [Monogrammisten] genua studiert hat.

[recto] Good Shepherd. The dead tree (the right one of the three on the left, cf. Jan B. Adoration, N.G.? Vienna, etc. Symbolism: dead trees on left against the delicate fresh foliage on right. Death & new life!; The Lambs painted thinly over the drawing (esp. the tempera on canvas) completely different from Northwich picture; The 'good' sleeve and the trousers typical P.B.I. Although the inclusion of short parallel lines for shading also in Northwich, the sleeve is not; [verso] like a sack, as it appears in the Northwich picture.

Ad [Addendum] P.B.I Jonah (lost). For my own use: This may well be a composition based on the lost Jonah. It is closer to P.B.I than the other Jonah compositions by Jan B. or others artists near P.B.I. The waves and the architecture are quite different from P.B.I but the rocks and the placing of the rockislands in the sea is comparable to Bruegel, e.g. in the Icarus. The shelfs in the foreground typical J.B.

Arthur M. Hind, An introduction to a History of Woodcut. [With a Detailed Survey of the Work Done in the Fifteenth Century, London: Constable], 1935, II, citaat p. 335: Two books printed by FRIEDRICH RIEDRER at Freiburg im Breisgau deserve mention as containing cuts now attributed to Dürer, about 1493 ([Willi] Kurth, [Albrecht] Dürer, [Sämtliche Holzschnitte, München: Holbein Verlag, 1927], 82) with a cut of the Virgin adored, by A. Bonstellen, and Riedrer's own Spiegel der wahren Rhetorik 1493 (s. 5096, H. 13914; Kurth, Dürer, 83, 84) with an excellent title-cut and an interesting rendering of the Fall of Icarus. [Vastgehecht met paperclip: krantenknipsel met afbeelding en onderschrift]: 'The first printed presentation of flight: 'The Flight of Daedalus and the Fall of Icarus', from a woodcut by Riederer, 1493, reproduced in 'The Birth of Flight', [in  handschrift]: An Anthology by Hartley Kemball Cook, [London: Allen & Unwin], 1941.

[Giorgio Faggin, L’ opera completa di Memling], Classici dell’arte [27], Rizzoli, Milano, 1969, N°. 19c (Bottega di Memling). Also contacts in details: Christ blessing etc. and the 3 women coming from the left. The lit up sky and some of the soldiers related. Important: The Italian XVI c. character of the torso of Christ, when compared with Flemish Late Gothic foreshortening particularly striking.

The folder contains handwritten, very detailed, timelines on Rubens' life and work, with references to his network, travelling, commissions and seemingly also references to his correspondence. They are the manuscript for the first chapter, 'Zeittafeln', in Evers' publication [*Rubens und sein Werk : neue Forschungen*](https://anet.be/record/rub/opacrub/c:lvd:13258322/N).   
There seem to be tree versions: one (with a red screen) starting in 1612 and ending in 1640 (the early years and 1613 are missing); the second one (with the pages numbered unevenly) starting in 1602 and ending in 1641; and the last one (rather small and multiple years per page) starting in 1600 and ending in 1641 (with a gap between 1608 and 1629, so probably a part is missing). 

The back sides of the pages were used to create a 19th-century timeline later on in Evers' career.

Allerlei verzamelde documenten (van Rooses en andere handen) over de brieven van Rubens die vermoedelijk dienden ter voorbereiding van de uitgave *Correspondance de Rubens et documents épistolaires concernant sa vie et ses oeuvres* die door Rooses en [Charles Ruelens]( https://anet.be/record/isaarrub/au::16168/N) werd uitgegeven van 1887 t.e.m. 1909. 
Het gaat om notities, transcripties van brieven, excerpten uit literatuur en briefwisseling. In de band bevinden zich heel wat stukken die afkomstig zijn van Noël Sainsbury en mogelijk door hem aan Rooses werden toegestuurd.

Bevat transcripties van allerhande publicaties - waaronder ook veilingcatalogi en krantenartikelen - evenals archivalia in verband met Rubens, steeds vergezeld van een bronvermelding. De getranscribeerde stukken dateren hoofdzakelijk uit de tweede helft van de 19de eeuw, hoewel er af en toe ook een ouder stuk tussen lijkt te zitten.

Bij heel wat transcripties werden aan het begin in de kantlijn opmerkingen toegevoegd als "af"[?], "utilisé", "utilisé transcrit", "à consulter". Het lijkt er dus op dat Rooses dit boekje gebruikte om interessante informatie te registeren die hij diende te bekijken voor zijn onderzoek en/of diende te integreren in zijn publicaties. In die zin geeft het stuk een idee van de werkwijze van Rooses als kunsthistoricus.
Een van de transcripties lijkt in feite een kladversie van een brief te zijn, gedateerd 15/01/1881. Hieruit kunnen we min of meer de ontstaansperiode van het boekje afleiden.

Het boekje is opgedeeld in twee met de hand genummerde delen (pagina 1 (6 pagina's ervoor niet genummerd) t.e.m. [184] en 1 t.e.m. [192]). Helemaal achteraan bevinden zich tafels van de twee delen en een tafel specifiek op de handschriften van François Mols.
Op p. 106 t.e.m. 172 van het eerste deel worden in de bovenhoeken data uit het leven van Rubens genoteerd. Daarop volgt een reeks pagina's met chronologisch één datum per pagina waarop telkens biografische info staat.
In het tweede deel worden verschillende specifieke thema's besproken: vanaf p. 69 een gelijkaardige opdeling per datum, maar ditmaal met een chronologische opsomming van de werken van Rubens, gevolgd door info over samenwerkingen. Vanaf p. 119 gaat het over de brieven van Rubens, op p. 151 over zijn schilderstijl, vanaf p. 154 over graveurs die naar Rubens werkten, op p. 165 over de kenmerken aan de hand waarvan zijn werken gedateerd kunnen worden, op p. 166 kort over tekeningen, op p. 167-168 over algemene kenmerken van zijn werk, op p. 171-173 over werken in musea in de Provence, op p. 173-175 over wat Moretus over Rubens schreef en op p. 176-186 over kerken waarin zich werken van Rubens bevinden.

Er zijn ook enkele losse stukken aanwezig:

  • Vooraan zit een losse nota van Rooses met enkele nummers en daarachter namen van kunstenaars.
  • Achteraan zit nog een verzameling niet ingebonden notities, genummerd van 1 t.e.m. 79 en vervolgens nog drie ongenummerde pagina's. Een ander ongenummerd blad is rond de bundel gebouwen. Deze notities lijken voornamelijk te gaan over de handschriften van Mols. Bovenaan op de pagina's werd in potlood genoteerd "vu".
  • Vooraan zat ook een nota van Nora De Poorter, "Mols nrs door Rooses overgeschreven", met verwijzingen naar nummeringen uit de publicatie Rubeniana van François Mols waar Rooses heel wat aandacht aan besteedt in zijn transcripties. Deze nota werd bij het stuk gehouden vanwege de mogelijk nuttige informatie die het verschaft.
